file_content.text: Corellia's free, and the Empire's on the run. The end of the war's in sight.
Supreme Chancellor Saresh, Senators--the Republic's taken the Legislature and the Empire's on their last legs. It's all cleanup from here.
The message went out across Corellia, and I'm proud to relay it to you on Coruscant. We will have our victory.
We had plenty of help from our allies, but one squad stood above the rest. We owe our victory to their efforts.
We had plenty of help from our allies, but one man stood above the rest. We owe our victory to his efforts.
We had plenty of help from our allies, but one woman stood above the rest. We owe our victory to her efforts.
I had a feeling I'd see you again, Master Jedi. Few others could win this fight.
I'm pleased to see you again, Major. You've done every man and woman in uniform proud.
On behalf of the Senate, I'd like to thank you for your service to the Republic. The general tells us you were indispensable.
It took more than firepower to free Corellia from the Empire.
It was a big job.
General Aves and Captain Cantarus gave the orders.
I didn't fight alone.
We haven't forgotten. They'll both be honored for their leadership.
I expect more than thanks for a fight like that.
Where's my medal?
The Senate understands the risk you took. You'll be rewarded handsomely.
The Corellian Council's decision to join the Empire must be addressed. Councillor Belos will answer for them.
I know you consider us all traitors. But before the Senate condemns us, I'd like a chance to explain.
The Corellian Council doubted the Republic's chances of defeating the Empire. We chose to join them rather than be conquered.
Some of my fellow councillors still believe this was the right choice. I believe it brought ruin to Corellia and war to the Republic.
Coming to us helped reverse some of the damage.
You did the right thing.
A few years in jail might change their minds.
The council's been punished.
My colleagues may never regret their decision. For that, I pity them.
Admitting your mistake won't bring back the dead.
That doesn't excuse you.
I know that. Captain Cantarus has been kind enough to show me the casualty lists.
I've done what I can to help the Republic win. With the Senate's permission, I'll spend the rest of my term restoring Corellia.
Do you expect the Senate to believe that? You gave Corellia to the Empire once. You might do it again.
Councillor Belos risked his life to undo the council's decision.
You can trust him.
It's true, Chancellor. If it weren't for Councillor Belos, we'd still be sitting in the Red Light Sector.
You have friends in high places, Councillor. Keep your position, but don't betray their trust.
Councillor Belos deserves a pardon, but he can't be trusted.
Make him step down.
I've served Corellia for decades. But I suppose my freedom was the best I could hope for.
There are other ways to serve Corellia, Councillor. The Senate hopes you'll take advantage of them.
The Senate's heard many rumors about the Imperial invasion of Corellia. Before we continue, we'd like to hear the truth.
The Empire moved in with the Corellian Council's blessing. We fought their inside knowledge all the way to Capitol Square.
The council showed no remorse for their actions. They've been arrested and removed from office.
The council was loyal to the Republic for years. Why would they abandon us now?
The Empire convinced them that we were weak.
They lost faith in us.
The council went with the odds. Fortunately for us, they didn't pay off.
The council forgot they answered to the people.
Too much power.
After all the noise we made, I don't think they'll forget again.
Those traitors will never control Corellia again.
It doesn't matter.
With the council in jail, Corellia has no local leadership. There could be riots, crime sprees, further destruction.
After all the damage the Empire's done, the Senate is hesitant to take direct control. Who should lead Corellia through their recovery?
We've got a war to fight. CorSec can handle things here.
The Corellians.
We'll hold elections for a new council soon. Should be nice not answering to anyone for a while.
Corellia's free, but vulnerable. They'll need our protection.
The Republic.
The Senate can appoint an interim prime minister. We'll declare martial law until then.
Corellia is one of our founding planets. There was no warning before they turned. How many more worlds might be on the brink?
You brought Corellia back to the Republic. You have the Senate's attention. How can we prevent other worlds from joining the Empire?
Corellia might look bad now, but all the Empire's destruction can be undone.
Don't let them lose hope.
This isn't our first victory, and it won't be our last. We will have peace.
The Republic won't stop fighting until the Empire surrenders. Neither will I.
Inspiring words. The Senate will support your efforts.
Corellia joined the Empire, and look what it brought them. War tore this world apart.
Remind them of the cost.
The council chose badly in a weak moment. Other worlds shouldn't make the same mistake.
When you abandon the Republic, you lose our protection. Traitors are on their own.
Many worlds have been allowed to rejoin the Republic. Maybe Corellia should be the last.
Even in times of war, the Republic attracts others seeking freedom from the Empire.
Keep your allies happy.
We've found our allies in unlikely places, ready and willing to fight for us.
Make good on your promises. Support all the worlds that came to our aid.
After the war is over, our new allies will have whatever they need.
The Republic lost faith in the order after the Battle of Coruscant. The order lost faith in itself.
Look to the Jedi.
We've learned much since then. The Children of the Emperor can no longer hide from us.
You'll need our insight to root out any traitors. Recall the Jedi to Coruscant.
The Jedi have proven their strength. The Senate welcomes their guidance.
We've watched countless worlds fall to the Empire. Every time, the Republic has fought and won them back.
Believe in the Republic.
The Empire might be willing to sacrifice anything to win, but Republic soldiers are better.
We'll never give up, and we'll never surrender. Fight with us, not against us.
If any Republic worlds want proof, they need only look to the major's example.
The best soldiers in the galaxy serve the Republic. But you're not using us to our full potential.
It's time to get rough.
If we keep letting the Empire make the first move, we'll lose more than a few planets.
Go on the offensive. Conquer a few Imperial worlds. No one will call the Republic weak again.
The Empire has no interest in peace. Maybe it's time the Republic stopped trying.
Corellia's free because the people fought back. Their reward is a big pile of rubble they used to call home.
Put the people first.
Some people call that the cost of war. I call it unfair. The Republic's too focused on the big picture.
Take care of the little guys first. You never know when you might need their help.
You have the Senate's promise. We'll see Corellia properly restored.
The Republic's got a lot of promise. But it's also got a lot of laws.
Loosen up a little.
Some of the galaxy's most brilliant don't play by the rules--but their creativity could be our edge on the Empire.
Make the Republic attractive to these--outliers--and the ends will easily justify the means.
An unorthodox approach. But we'll consider your words.
You're the politicians.
Before you go, we'd like to thank you properly. There's no medal or title that equals what you've accomplished, but this should help.
First Class Bloodstripes, Corellia's highest honor. Awarded to those who keep fighting despite the odds.
Thank you, Captain. I'd be proud to fight with CorSec again.
I am honored.
We'd be proud to have you. But I'm hoping our fighting days are nearly over.
With Corellia free, what's the Republic's next objective?
It's not over yet.
The Empire will have a hard time recovering from this loss. We hit them now, and we could have a surrender within weeks.
I also ended a blockade, beat the Imperial Guard, took on the Dark Council....
Stripes? That's it?
When we can fit all that on a medal, we'll contact you.
You've freed Corellia from the Empire and set events in motion that may end this war. You deserve more than our thanks.
Our victory today sends a message. The Republic may falter, but we will never fall--as long as we keep fighting.
Senators, let your voices be heard. Stand and recognize these heroes of the Republic!
Storming the Legislature will be tricky. Cole Cantarus will know where to start.
With Axial Park under control, Capitol Square is just a tram ride away. We've already started planning our offensive.
The Legislature will be our primary target. The Empire's turned it into a fortress. It'll take more than firepower to get inside.
What is the Legislature, exactly?
The Legislature?
The seat of Corellian government. Imperial officers, the Corellian Council and everyone else who started this little war are holed up inside.
Do we have any information about their defenses?
That's pretty vague intel.
Councillor Belos might know a few shortcuts.
We have an inside man.
The councillor's risked his neck for us already. We contact him now, he might lose it altogether.
Cole Cantarus is familiar with the Legislature's security from his days in the Council Guard. He'll be our best starting point.
You'll find Captain Cantarus at the Council Guardhouse in Capitol Square. He should be able to brief you.
Let Cantarus know I'm on my way.
I'll head there next.
What has Captain Cantarus been doing?
He's been busy, huh?
Mobilizing our CorSec allies. We'll need them when the time comes.
Cantarus's information could be wrong.
Things have changed.
If that's the case, we'll go to the councillor. But we can't go in blind.
I'll get back to troop deployment. When we know our next move, my men will be ready.
You've arrived just in time to witness the final troop deployment into Axial Park.
The Empire's making a last stand. It might get messy, but we can hold our ground.
Commander Tainor's already been transferred offworld. A lot of people wanted him dead.
He already lost. There was no reason to kill him.
He deserved to live.
Some people live for the extra twist of the blade. I'm glad you're not one of them.
His capture meant more than his death.
It sent a message.
It definitely affected the Empire's morale. When they stumbled, we made our move.
Helping him fall on his sword didn't appeal to me.
I don't do executions.
Some time in a cell could change his perspective. Maybe he'll stop thinking devotion and start thinking revenge.
The Emperor's probably put a price on his head.
He'd be dead if he stayed.
A bounty hunter might be preferable to the Emperor's brand of punishment.
What are the Republic's plans for the commander?
What will happen to him?
Our most secure detention center and a lot of SIS interrogations. Maybe even his tactical advice, someday.
The Imperial Guard's been defeated. What's next?
He's no longer a threat.
I must have called my men at least three times to verify Commander Tainor's death.
The Emperor will have to do better than that to stop me.
He didn't have a chance.
Since you're the best we've got against him, here's hoping he can't.
He refused to surrender. He was too dangerous to be spared.
I didn't have a choice.
I'll second that. Wherever he is, the commander's probably thinking of ways he could have won.
The Imperial Guard had orders to kill me.
It became personal.
I'm surprised it didn't happen sooner. The Empire knows you're our ace in the hole.
Can't argue with a man who wants to die.
He wanted it that way.
Not if you hope to win, anyway. The Imperial Guard's code of honor could put the Mandalorians to shame.
Winning is what I do.
I wouldn't have sent you in there if I didn't think you'd make it out.
The war's not over yet.
We have to protect our command center. Keep those troops safe until the trenches are done.
Checking in, General Aves. Captain Cantarus said you needed me.
If we need you anywhere on Corellia, it's here. We're getting close and the Imperials know it.
We've been on the march since the blockade ended. When we reached Axial Park, the Empire was waiting.
Axial Park is the gateway to Capitol Square and a monument to Republic history. Failure isn't an option here.
We have the Force on our side. Failure isn't a possibility.
It won't come to that.
I'll trust you on that one. What Jedi are left on Corellia didn't respond to our calls for aid.
I can offer you squads from several offworld ambassadors.
We do have allies here.
Solid thought but we'd never get them here in time.
I'm ready to fight, sir.
Sabotage squads, snipers, you name it--all led by some elite commanders we haven't been able to identify.
No worries, General. Failure isn't even in my vocabulary.
Not since I showed up.
I had a feeling it wasn't. Or that you wouldn't admit to it.
What's our battle plan?
Monuments and history aren't worth dying for.
Antiques aren't important.
The Republic is. And we've let the Empire trample on her for too long.
Every time we gain some ground, our troops get ambushed. Between the special forces and the Imperial army, my men are overwhelmed.
We're about to start a major offensive into Imperial territory. I need someone on the battlefield dealing with these ambushes as they appear.
Whatever the Empire throws at me, I can handle it.
You can count on me.
I believe it.
Can I count on any reinforcements or backup?
Will I have any help?
Afraid not. CorSec is holding the rest of Corellia, and my troops will have their hands full with the Imperial army.
That's quite a big job.
We've got to secure the ground we have. Our engineers are creating a perimeter of trenches around the command center.
The engineers have armed escorts, but the Empire's hit them hard. They'll need your protection until the trenches are stabilized.
Tell your men to get working. I'll keep the Empire busy.
I'll do my best.
Move fast and take 'em down hard. There's too much at stake for games.
You'll need more than trenches to defeat the Empire.
And then what?
Your men will survive if they stay out of my way.
No promises.
If things go south, those trenches are our last defense. The men building them are not expendable.
I've got my scouts working to find special forces before they strike. As reports come in, I'll contact you with your next objective.
Make sure you're prepared before you head out. There's no time to rest on a battlefield.
If the Empire's droids are the problem, we need to get rid of them. Councillor Belos's assistant will know how.
What's important is we have access to the rocket tram. We're already moving troops and supplies to Republic holdouts across Corellia.
But the Empire's not making it easy. Once our reinforcements move from the rocket tram to ground transport, they disappear.
We're not sure how the Empire's catching them, but someone contacted us who thinks he does.
Councillor Belos, of the same Corellian Council that voted to join the Empire.
That was a mistake. The Republic's trying to free Corellia. I want to help.
You voted against the Republic. Why would you help us now?
Now it's a mistake?
You've broken the Imperial blockade. The Republic wouldn't have had a chance otherwise.
Nice of you to support us now that the Empire's losing.
The council's vote was unanimous. What made you change your mind?
Why help us now?
Half of Corellia is in ruins. The Senate's condemned us, the people are rioting... it's bad business.
And business would be all you care about, wouldn't it?
You're an Imperial now. Everything you say could be a lie.
How can we trust you?
If the Empire wanted to trick you, they'd use someone you trust.
Puts you out of the running. But I'm still not convinced.
You're lucky the Republic even answered your comm call.
You're kidding, right?
I want to see Corellia restored. Only the Republic can do that.
Empire hasn't kept the peace on Corellia like you hoped?
Talk fast, Councillor.
We don't need a traitor's help.
Thanks, but no thanks.
I'm risking my life to contact you--the least you could do is hear me out.
We're risking our lives every day to undo the council's decision. We don't owe you a thing.
I'm not asking for forgiveness, but your reinforcements will never get through Labor Valley without my help.
Your men disappear once they move to speeders. The Empire's using prototype droids that can bring down any short-range vehicle.
Where did the Empire find this technology?
Sounds advanced.
Not found, developed. They've rounded up the best scientists and technicians on Corellia and put them to work.
What's Labor Valley?
Labor Valley?
The industrial center of Corellia. The galaxy's best fuel yards and factories are there, along with plenty of people fighting for them.
You could be lying.
The council interacts with the heads of the Empire on a daily basis.
My assistant, Deena Behar, has been researching the droids. I've instructed her to meet you in Labor Valley. Can she expect you?
We'll take whatever information your assistant can offer.
Tell her I'll be there.
I'll trust you for now.
I'm a lot of things, but a liar isn't one of them. I suppose I'll have to prove that to you first.
Better not be a trick.
The Empire would do worse. Believe me, I want the Republic to win.
I should get back before I'm missed. If I learn anything else that might help, I'll contact you.
If this is a trap, we'll find out soon enough. Take the rocket tram to Labor Valley and find this Deena Behar. We need to stop those droids.
You made it out. We've been busy--Coronet Shipping's still a mess, but the rocket trams are up and running.
The neutron emitters worked perfectly. The Imperials on board didn't even have a chance to attack.
Tell that to the civilians trying to escape the war. They didn't deserve to become casualties.
If there had been any way to save them, I would have.
I didn't want them to die.
You had a way. It just required the Republic to risk something, too.
Saving those civilians might have cost the Republic their reinforcements.
Look at the big picture here.
There are plenty of people willing to fight. The people who died can't be replaced.
In war, every resource counts. The Imperials would have done too much damage.
There was no other option.
I get it--the risk of losing was too high. Can't expect the Republic army to fight.
They took a chance trying to escape. It turned out bad.
No one made them sneak a ride.
You might call the sacrifice of a couple of Corellian families bad. Some might call it wrong.
I made my decision. We need to focus on beating the Empire.
It's over now, Captain.
I don't answer to CorSec.
There's no way you could justify it to me anyway.
There were over two dozen civilians on those trams. Thanks to you a lot of them are already offworld.
I'd be happier if any of them had stayed to help. We've lost supplies and men all over this sector.
Innocent people were going to die. I had to do something.
Civilians come first, General.
At the Republic's expense. We'll recover, but we might not be so lucky next time.
Using the neutron emitters would have made us no better than the Empire.
That's the price of honor.
I suppose you're right. Victory by any means is their department.
War is part of our job. Civilians shouldn't get caught in the cross fire.
Soldiers can take that risk.
The people of Corellia joined the war when they decided to resist the Empire. We're both fighting to win.
I don't kill innocent people. Just a little policy I have.
There were civilians involved.
There's a difference between innocent and recklessly putting yourself in harm's way.
I made my choice. The Republic will have to make do.
It's over now, at any rate.
Don't like my help, don't ask.
Don't think I'm ungrateful. It was your call, and it won't be the last.
This is it. Get inside Coronet Shipping and find those neutron emitters.
Cantarus has the details on getting inside the Selonian tunnels.
We need the Selonians' support. Evacuate those burrows.
Get to that cell block. The Imperials won't hold a CorSec captain and a Selonian leader forever.
Nearly every place on Corellia has a back door. CorSec thinks some of the Selonian tunnels run right under Coronet Shipping.
The Selonians haven't dealt much with the Republic, so I sent a Corellian to do the negotiating. He should have been back by now.
I've never heard of the Selonians.
The Selonians?
One of Corellia's native species. They were tunnel dwellers, until the Empire cut off their supplies--
Who is this Corellian, exactly? Can he be trusted?
Bad pick, maybe.
Cole Cantarus, a former captain in CorSec's Council Guard. The man's impulsive, but he hasn't let me down yet--
Let's not lose our heads yet. The Imperials don't make it easy to move around Corellia--
Sir--Imperials attacked the rendezvous point. Captain Cantarus and the Selonian have been captured.
Someone tipped off the Imperials! Do we know where they're being held?
There's a captured CorSec station nearby. It would have the cell blocks and fortifications they'd need.
CorSec needs to keep the Red Light Sector secure. You've got to free Captain Cantarus and his Selonian contact.
If they've been interrogated, the Empire might know your plans.
What if they talked?
If they haven't, we're in the clear. Either way, I don't trust them with the Imperials for long.
I'm already on my way.
Do we even know if they're still alive?
This is a waste of time.
The Empire wouldn't have captured them if they didn't think they were worth something.
These CorSec stations have room for plenty more prisoners. Help them if you can, but Cantarus and his contact are your primary concern.
I'll put CorSec on alert and tell my scouts to watch for any sign of them. Get going.
Welcome to the Gilded Descent. CorSec had the intel on the neutron emitters ready and waiting for us.
The emitters are at Coronet Shipping. They're a major distributor of starship parts and weapons. Place is built like a fortress.
Unfortunately, the Empire's using it as shock troop headquarters. That makes a straight assault impossible. Too many defenses.
Can we bring those defenses down somehow?
We're sure about that?
With a few months of careful planning, maybe. But we don't have that kind of time.
How do we get inside?
We beat the shock troops around the spaceport, didn't we?
You're such a pessimist.
That was just a few patrols. We're talking about a fully staffed and heavily armed HQ.
The minute we see smoke from those supply camps, my men and I will move out.
General Aves. I was told you could use some help.
And then some. I'm glad you all appreciate the importance of Corellia.
Master Jedi. I know the order's stretched thin, but the Empire's not going to give up easy.
Major. I was sure other objectives would keep you off the battlefield.
Captain. More than one officer has told me you can get things done.
Corporal Hartke explained we've lost access to the rocket trams, but he wasn't cleared to know why.
The Empire's gotten their hands on some modified neutron emitters. They're using them to wipe out anyone on board the trams.
Getting access to the tram is useless if we can't ride it.
But the trams are working?
The neutron emitters only affect life-forms. The trams themselves are still mechanically sound.
Are the Imperials attacking Corellian passengers, too?
Civilians and military both?
Unfortunately, yes. But it hasn't stopped them from trying to escape the more war-torn areas.
I'm guessing you discovered that the hard way.
You know from experience.
The minute we landed, I sent my best squads ahead on the tram. They were dead before they reached their stop.
The Republic has allies all over Corellia, but they're no help if we can't reach them. We've got to find those neutron emitters.
We've received word that CorSec may have intel on the neutron emitters' location. They've carved out a safe haven in the Red Light Sector.
What does CorSec stand for?
CorSec? Are they allies?
Corellian Security Force. Local law enforcement and our primary allies against the Empire.
Red Light Sectors are usually full of criminals.
Sure doesn't sound safe.
Not anymore. Lot of civilians hiding there. Most of the casinos, clubs and cantinas have been shut down.
Then why are we here?
Without trams, the only way to reach the Red Light Sector is on foot--and Imperial shock troops control what's in between.
If you attack the Empire's supply camps, the shock troops will be distracted. My escort will move to meet up with CorSec as fast as we can.
I'll keep the shock troops busy until you've gotten through safely.
No need to rush.
The path is littered with crashed ships and dead soldiers. I don't plan to linger.
Many troops will go to the supply camps, but others might not.
Still, go with caution.
Don't worry about us. My men know this is no walk in the park.
I've gotten pretty good at keeping the Imperials busy.
Take your time, sir.
That, I don't doubt--you've had the ops to prove it.
I'll make a big mess for the Imperials to clean up.
This ought to be fun.
We don't have time for hotshots. Get their attention and get out.
I can do that much.
You get caught, I might not be there to rescue you.
You're on your own.
My men are the Republic's finest. You do your job, and they'll do theirs.
Once you reach the Red Light Sector, meet me in the Gilded Descent. It's an old casino turned CorSec fortress.
I'll let CorSec know we're coming. We'll be right behind you.
The Imperials have us trapped here. We've got to get past the blockade.
Lieutenant Bokete mentioned special forces. Do we know any specifics?
Not if we're prepared.
Well, he's dead.
